required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Early Amniotomy Following Transcervical Foley Balloon in the Induction of Labor
clinical_study.official_title: Early Amniotomy Following Transcervical Foley Balloon in the Induction of Labor: a Randomized Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston

brief_summary.textblock: Amniotomy is commonly done in the management of labor, though there is little research guiding the timing of amniotomy. Recent research largely suggests a benefit to earlier amniotomy, reporting shorter labor courses with no increase in the number of cesarean deliveries. This is some research, however, that reports an increase in cesarean deliveries with early amniotomy. Due to the small number of studies evaluating this topic, as well as the conflicting results, more research is needed. Additionally, the method of cervical ripening prior to amniotomy should be accounted for, as it may have an impact on the overall labor course. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of early versus delayed amniotomy on time of delivery time from induction to the active phase of labor, as well on total time to delivery and maternal and neonatal outcomes in women undergoing cervical ripening with the Foley balloon.

detailed_description.textblock:
This will be an unblinded randomized clinical trial. The investigators will recruit 174 pregnant women undergoing induction of labor. Recruitment will occur on the Labor and Delivery unit at the time of induction, after the decision has been made to place a Foley balloon for cervical ripening. Enrolled subjects will be randomized to early or delayed amniotomy.
Subjects randomized to early amniotomy will undergo amniotomy within 2 hours of Foley balloon removal. Subjects randomized to delayed amniotomy will undergo amniotomy at least 4 hours after Foley balloon removal.

primary_outcome.measure: Time to active phase of labor
primary_outcome.description: Total time from initiation of labor induction to reaching 6 cm cervical dilation

secondary_outcome.description: Total time from initiation of labor induction to delivery
Rate of vaginal delivery within 24, 36, and 48 hours
Rate of cesarean section and indications

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge, up to 2 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Includes isolated maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, endometritis, wound infection

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge, up to 2 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Neonatal outcome composite including NICU admission, respiratory support, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, seizures, sepsis, meconium aspiration syndrome, birth trauma, intracranial or subgaleal hemorrhage, hypotension requiring pressors, and perinatal death.

arm_group.description: Subjects randomized to this arm will undergo amniotomy within 2 hours of removal of Foley balloon.
Subjects randomized to this arm will undergo amniotomy at least 4 hours after removal of Foley balloon.

intervention.description: The Foley balloon is inserted transcervically and inflated to a volume of 60 cc. It may be spontaneously expelled or manually removed if in place for 12 hours.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18
- Singleton pregnancy
- Term gestation (37 weeks gestation)
- Cephalic presentation
- Undergoing labor induction with transcervical Foley balloon
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous uterine surgery
- Prelabor rupture of membranes
- Severe pre-eclampsia, HELLP, or eclampsia
- HIV, HCV, or HBV
- Heart disease
- Fever (â‰¥38 0C) at admission
- Category II or III fetal heart rate tracing prior to randomization
- Polyhydramnios
- Fetal growth restriction <3%
- EFW > 4200 g
- Fetal demise or major congenital anomaly
- Prisoners
